answers.author: Anne Marie Green
answers.text:
We have had take home vehicles since the late 1980's.  The initial start up cost is a bear, but overall, we believe it does cost less in the long run.  The officers do take better care of their vehicles, and are responsible for getting them in for service at the regular intervals.  The vehicles are essentially their offices, since they spend so much time in them and have the MDTs.   We have around 130 in the fleet, and probably replace about 10 per year, based on mileage and age of the vehicle.  The vehicles last longer since they are not being run 24/7.  The PD does have a policy in place that prevents use for non-governmental travel, and since the vast majority of the vehicles are marked, it hasn't been that hard to enforce.

answers.author: Jessica Roth
answers.text:
We started providing take home police vehicles several years ago.  While our Chief cited some monetary benefits, it's really just a perk for the officers.  As most of the cities around us offered them, we felt we needed to do it in order to remain competitive.  We do feel that the officers take better care of the vehicles though since it is their assigned vehicle and they are more attuned to its maintenance needs.  Our policy permits the vehicles to travel a maximum distance to their homes (either 20 or 25 miles...would have to double check the policy).  If their home is beyond that, they have to park it at a police or fire station within that radius.  Their addresses are audited periodically to ensure they're in compliance with this.  The policy also prohibits non-City use.  If they violate the policy, they can lose this privilege.

answers.author: Gabe Gabrielsen
answers.text:
I will date myself on this one but "years ago" when we still had Ford Crown Vics as the lion's share of  L/E vehicles this issue came up over and over. 
I was the County Administrator in a large rural county.  No matter how we sliced it or diced it there were 7 significant pros and cons.  
I personnally supported take home vehicles because it made sense.  We got out the fleet maintenance and fleet rotation business.  
Below is a quick summary of the issues that always surfaced. 
1) Most officers did not want take home cars - especially their spouses - as there was no place to park them most homes have two car driveways or two car garages 
2) Maintenance cost cut dramatically.  On "hot seated" cars every officer is suppose to check fluid levels, air presssure etc. before their shift --- seldom done.  
Take home vehicles always had good preventive maintenance.  No officer wanted to be without his or her car.  
3)  I was in a large rural county.  If we needed additional officers to respond to an emergency officers with cars were on their way the minute they left home. 
4)  Many neighbors loved having a law enforcement vehicle parked in their area, they saw this as a plus - less speeders and they felt safer. 
5)  Few neighbors saw take home vehicles as an unnecessary privilege and a waste of taxpayer money to give a cop a free car.  And let us not forget the "Why is that cop home all the time doesn't he/she ever work. 
6)  Old Ford crown Vic's came with a 3 yr./ 36,000 mile warranty which ever came first. "Hot Seated" vehicles easily burnt through 36,000 miles in less then a year.  Take home went almost 3 yrs under warranty.  Our County policy was not to have L/E vehicles with over 100,000 miles - hot seated vehicles barely made it 2 years then had to be replaced, many take home vehicles lasted 5 years in service. 
7) If a "hot seated" vehicle was out of commission 3 or 4 officers scrambled to find a vehicle.  If a take home was out of commission 1 officer needed to find a replacement vehicle.   
Take Home Vehicles made sense to me.  Economic savings up, vehicle in service rates up and overall public relations/good will up , l. 
Gabe

author: David Dillner
text:
How many of your Police Departments have a "take home" fleet where individual officers are assigned their own patrol car? I am being told that this fleet management method saves dollars because officers are more inclined to take better care of an individual car than a shared vehicle. I find this somewhat difficult to believe for several reasons that I won't go into here. I would be curious as to everyone's thoughts on this type of system.
If you have this type of system, what rules or regulations do you have to ensure that patrol cars are only used to public uses?
Thanks.
title: Take Home Police Vehicles
